climbs.name: Turtle Days
climbs.fa: Roger Linfield and Dennis Yates, April 1987

content.description: Climb a thin crack with some good finger locks to where it ends.  A mantle (crux) takes you to two parallel shallow cracks.  Small wired nuts protect moves on very grainy rock to the top.
content.location: The lower formation on the left has two cracks on its northwest face.  This climb follows the left crack.

climbs.name: Smokestack Lightning
climbs.fa: Roger Linfield and Dennis Yates, April 1987

content.description: Follow a thin crack to a ledge, then climb a hand crack until it ends at a face with a bolt.  A weird crux sequence leads to a second bolt and the top.
content.protection: gear for finger and hand jamming, plus two bolts
content.location: This route follows a crack and face near the left end of the right formation, starting from the ground.

climbs.name: In Memory of Elizabeth Tortoise
climbs.fa: Dennis Yates and Roger Linfield, April 1987

content.description: To the right of Smokestack Lightning, do a few face moves, then mantle (crux) on large holds.  Steep flake climbing, again on large holds, leads to the top.
content.location: This is on the right of the two formations which make up Tortoiseville.

climbs.name: Goodness of Whole Grain
climbs.fa: Roger Linfield and Dennis Yates, April 1987

content.description: The rock on this climb is perhaps the grainiest of any route I've done in the park - tape up well!  A fist crack widens to an offwidth, bypassed by some face moves on the right.  Easier but runout climbing above leads to the top.
content.location: This follows a crack on the right side of the left, lower formation.
